title: RS22055
content: The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) provides federal funding for children with disabilities, requiring a free appropriate public education (FAPE) and due process provisions. Attorneys' fees provisions were added in 1986 and amended in 1997. The Handicapped Children's Protection Act, P.L. 99-372, added attorneys' fees provisions in 1986, amended in 1997, and further changed in 2004 under the IDEA reauthorization. The 2004 law aligned more with the Senate bill, S. 1248, maintaining previous provisions on attorneys' fees. The 2004 IDEA reauthorization aligned with the Senate bill, maintaining provisions on attorneys' fees. Changes included allowing attorneys' fees for the state or local educational agency against parents or their attorneys in certain situations. Complaint and appeals procedures remained similar, with the addition of the local educational agency being able to file a complaint. Parents or agencies can file complaints regarding various educational aspects and have the right to an impartial due process hearing with an opportunity to appeal. The 2004 reauthorization of IDEA allows for attorneys' fees to be awarded in certain situations, including against a parent's attorney if the complaint is deemed frivolous. This provision aims to ensure fair and reasonable legal proceedings for children with disabilities. The 2004 reauthorization of IDEA allows for attorneys' fees to be awarded if litigation is deemed frivolous, unreasonable, or without foundation. This provision aims to prevent improper purposes such as harassment or unnecessary delays in legal proceedings. Senator Grassley emphasized that the amendment does not discourage legitimate complaints against school districts but aims to prevent abuses of due process rights and ensure taxpayer dollars are used for educating children. Senator Gregg emphasized the need for the attorneys' fee amendment in the 2004 reauthorization of IDEA, stating that it aims to prevent abuses of due process rights and ensure taxpayer dollars are used for educating children, not for lining the pockets of unscrupulous trial lawyers. The attorneys' fee provision in the 2004 reauthorization of IDEA aims to protect defendants from burdensome litigation with no legal basis. Senator Gregg highlighted the high standard for prevailing defendants to recover fees and the consideration of plaintiffs' financial resources. The provision also allows for fee recovery if lawsuits are brought for an improper purpose, drawing from Rule 11 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. Attorneys' fees under the 2004 reauthorization of IDEA are based on prevailing community rates, with specific prohibitions and limitations. Fees cannot be awarded for services performed after a written settlement offer under certain conditions, and no bonus or multiplier is allowed. Senator Gregg emphasized the objective reasonableness standard in interpreting Rule 11 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure for fee recovery. The 2004 reauthorization of IDEA introduced provisions for attorneys' fees, including restrictions on when fees can be awarded and the requirement for a "resolution session" before a due process hearing. Fees are based on prevailing community rates, with limitations on services performed after a settlement offer. Senator Gregg emphasized the objective reasonableness standard for fee recovery. Attorneys' fees under P.L. 108-446 can be awarded to a prevailing parent if they were justified in rejecting a settlement offer. Fees may be reduced if the resolution process is unreasonably prolonged, costs exceed community rates, services are excessive, or if necessary information was not provided to the school district. Attorneys' fees under P.L. 108-446 can be awarded to a prevailing parent if they were justified in rejecting a settlement offer. Fees may be reduced if the resolution process is unreasonably prolonged, costs exceed community rates, services are excessive, or if necessary information was not provided to the school district. The final regulations for P.L. 108-446 were issued on August 14, 2006, with specific exceptions for fee reduction. The final regulations for P.L. 108-446 were issued on August 14, 2006, with the Department of Education declining to provide further guidance on the interpretation of statutory language regarding attorneys' fees. They did not address whether non-attorney advocates could receive compensation for their services at due process hearings. The Department of Education declined to award fees to non-attorney advocates at due process hearings, citing the Supreme Court's decision in Arlington Central School District Board of Education v. Murphy. The 2004 reauthorization of IDEA did not include explicit language authorizing recovery of experts' fees for prevailing parents.
